Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of standing Isis-Hathor wearing festival wreath headdress, with hair worn long in Isis locks. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. White (gypsum?) coating. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Hellenion (Naukratis), Site 11 (Hogarth) and Site 26 (Hogarth), near surface
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally made at Naukratis. Similar to 3rd to 2nd century BC parallels in the British Museum (Bailey 2008, nos 3006) and Ptolemaic to Roman Isis figures in the Louvre (Dunand 1990, particularly no. 360). Many similar Isis figurines were found at Naukratis and are now in Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology (NA465, NA605, NA665, NA719, may be from same figure as NA845) and the British Museum (Bailey 2008, no. 2997, GR1888,0601.110). Isis figures have also been found in Cyprus (Karageorghis 1999, pl. 32.10, no. 2(7)196). Dunand, F. 1990. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte. Paris Karageorghis, J. 1999. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus.V. The Cypro-Archaic Period small female figurines. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.173) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 82, nos 43-45)
